TopicTitle: Dna, combinations, rng and the magic boulder are on a boat.

Articles.Content:
Just brainstorming around some simple math thingy and wanted to share them.

What the probability that the "gene" (fragment sum total/partial/similar) responsible of sonar for bat and dolphin to happen in a single human

What the probability that the gene(s^?) responsible of pheromone sensistivities for dog and ants happen for a single human

What the probability that the gene(s^?) responsible of magnetic field sensistivities for cats happen for a single human

What the probability that the gene(s^?) responsible of (some specific whatever existing animal) sensitivities/"competence"  happen within a single human genetic code

just curious how everyone feel about that kind of thing, possible, impossible, etc ?
may the said single/multiple sensisitivities amplitudes differ from one human to another in case it could eventually happen ?
is there a notice on e-bay ? ( ^^jk with that's last one )

Edited September 22, 2016 by WinkAllKerb''
pidgin in glitch because tired

Incredibly low, because genetic mutation doesn't work that way. Mutations don't randomly cause something radically different most of the time. Usually it's more of a gradual drift in a random direction.

3 hours ago, Streetwind said:

Incredibly low, because genetic mutation doesn't work that way. Mutations don't randomly cause something radically different most of the time. Usually it's more of a gradual drift in a random direction.

This, note that with genetic engineering you could copy and paste. Well not exactly you wanted to modify it a bit too. 
Increasing smell would probably be easiest we have an decent area behind the nose and could expand the nose bridge a bit without looking weird. You need more brain area for processing but human brains are huge compared to dogs. 

Are cats sensitive to electrical fields? I thought the just created them rubbing on stuff.
Now cat night vision would be pretty easy but your eyes would look like an cat at least the reflecting eyes, you might be able to avoid the cat eye however the small pupil would probably look worse.

13 hours ago, WinkAllKerb'' said:

What the probability that the gene(s^?) responsible of pheromone sensistivities for dog and ants happen for a single human

This problem can be easily solved from the opposite side: enforce pheromones, stop washing.

Other points: zero. All listed abilities are negligible for survival or social rank. A human depends on technology much more, and this dependence will keep increasing with future technological progress. No need in night vision when you have a lamp.
